metadata.chief_complaint: anxiety visit but teen deflects to TikTok, friend drama, eventually opens up about panic attacks

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Hey Chloe. Your mom scheduled this visit because she's worried about you. What's going on?

script.speaker: teen
script.text: Nothing. I'm fine. She worries too much.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: She's not fine. She's been in her room constantly. She barely eats. Something's wrong.

script.speaker: teen
script.text: Mom, can you not?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Let me talk to Chloe for a bit. Mom, want to wait outside and I'll call you back in?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Fine. But please talk to her.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Okay, just us. What's actually going on in your life?

script.speaker: teen
script.text: Ugh, nothing. I'm just tired of her asking me what's wrong all the time.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: That sounds annoying. What have you been up to lately?

script.speaker: teen
script.text: Just school. And my phone. Did you see that TikTok about the girl who got locked in a bathroom at school?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: I haven't. Is TikTok a big thing for you?

script.speaker: teen
script.text: I mean yeah, everyone's on it. I spend like hours on it.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: What kind of stuff do you watch?

script.speaker: teen
script.text: Funny stuff. Drama. There's this whole thing with my friend group right now that's like straight out of a TikTok.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Oh yeah? What's happening?

script.speaker: teen
script.text: So my friend Maddie told Emma that I said something about her but I literally didn't, and now Emma won't talk to me and they're both being weird.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: That sounds stressful.

script.speaker: teen
script.text: It's so dumb. I don't even care.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: How does it make you feel when you think about seeing them at school?

script.speaker: teen
script.text: I don't know. Anxious I guess.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Tell me about that anxiety. What does it feel like?

script.speaker: teen
script.text: Just... nervous. Like my stomach hurts.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Has it ever gotten really bad? Like beyond just nervous?

script.speaker: teen
script.text: I mean... there was this one time.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Tell me about it.

script.speaker: teen
script.text: It was at school. I was in the cafeteria and suddenly I couldn't breathe. My heart was pounding so hard I thought I was dying. I had to go to the nurse.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: That sounds terrifying. How long did it last?

script.speaker: teen
script.text: Maybe like ten minutes? It felt like forever. The nurse said it was a panic attack.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Has it happened again since then?

script.speaker: teen
script.text: Yeah. Like three more times. Once at home, twice at school.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Do you know what triggered them?

script.speaker: teen
script.text: The one at home was when my parents were fighting about money. At school, I don't know. Maybe just being around people.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: So you're having panic attacks. Why didn't you tell your mom?

script.speaker: teen
script.text: I don't want her to freak out. She already treats me like I'm broken.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: You're not broken. Panic attacks are really common, especially in teenagers. They're treatable.

script.speaker: teen
script.text: Really?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Yeah. They're your body's alarm system going off when there's no real danger. We can teach you how to manage them.

script.speaker: teen
script.text: I don't want to take pills.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: That's not the first step anyway. The first step is learning techniques to calm your body down when it happens. Breathing exercises, grounding techniques. A therapist can teach you.

script.speaker: teen
script.text: Therapy sounds weird.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: It's just talking to someone who specializes in this stuff. Like talking to me, but they have more time and more tools.

script.speaker: teen
script.text: I guess I can try it.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Good. I'm going to teach you one thing right now. When you feel a panic attack starting, try breathing in for four counts, holding for four, and out for four. Can you practice with me?

script.speaker: teen
script.text: Okay. In, two, three, four. Hold, two, three, four. Out, two, three, four.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Perfect. Do that as soon as you feel the symptoms starting. It won't make it disappear but it can make it shorter.

script.speaker: teen
script.text: Thanks. Do you have to tell my mom everything?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: I'm going to tell her you're having anxiety and panic attacks and we have a plan. I won't tell her the details of our conversation. But she needs to know enough to support you.

script.speaker: teen
script.text: Okay. That's fair.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Let's bring her back in.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: What did you find out?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Chloe's been dealing with anxiety and panic attacks. She was brave enough to open up about it. We're going to get her into therapy and she's going to be okay.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Panic attacks? Oh honey, why didn't you tell me?

script.speaker: teen
script.text: I didn't want you to worry.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: The good news is we can help. I'll send over a referral to a therapist, and let's follow up in four weeks.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Thank you, Doctor. Thank you, Chloe, for talking.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Chloe, remember, four-four-four breathing. And text your mom when you're feeling anxious instead of hiding in your room. Deal?

script.speaker: teen
script.text: Deal.
